wikipedia_page.main: Joseph Murray Ince (1806–1859) was a British painter known for his landscapes, drawings, and watercolours of local scenes in Wales and paintings of Cambridge and Oxford colleges.

response: Between 1823 and 1826 he had Joseph Murray Ince as a pupil.James Murray Ince, Dictionary of National Biography

The Market Hall (demolished in the 1860’s) Weobley Conservation Area Appraisal, Weobley Parish Council 2006 p. 6 was a fine timber-framed building allegedly erected by John Abel (1578-1675), and located on the south-east corner of the marketplace infill. It has a large upper chamber over an open ground floor, supported by ornately carved timber posts.Seeley, Jackson and Halliday: The Portfolio, An Artistic Periodical 1888 p. 150 A drawing of it survives by Joseph Murray Ince 1839, which is now at the Rhode Island School of Design Museum in the USA. Also, paintings by William Pitt of the mid 19th century feature it.
**Joseph Murray Ince, painter (died 1859)James Murray Ince, Dictionary of National Biography

In 2006, the bicentennial of Joseph Murray Ince was celebrated with an exhibition.Caroline Lewis, Hereford Museum & Art Gallery Celebrates Joseph Murray Ince Bicentenary, Culture 24, UK, 3 August 2006.

link_mentions.page: University of Cambridge in popular culture
response: The colleges of Cambridge University were painted by several artists in the seventeenth and nineteenth centuries, including William Westall, Myles Birket Foster, Thomas Rowlandson, Richard Bankes Harraden, and Joseph Murray Ince.
